=== Correlation with Dualist Christianity vs. Secularity ===
 
It is often suggested, especially in a Western context, that without the god-given moral imperatives like the biblical [[10 commandments]], moral standards would eventually evaporate.
 
It is often suggested, especially in a Western context, that without the god-given moral imperatives like the biblical [[10 commandments]], moral standards would eventually evaporate.
 
At least two scholars, Paul and Jensen, have been addressing this problem using statistics of homicide, abortion, sexually transmittable diseases and more. They found that such a loss of morality does not seem to be borne out in the data he studied. If anything, among western democracies, it might be the other way around, especially for dualist christianity, that is to say in societies where the belief both that a God and a devil exist is strong.<ref name = "Paul">[[Gregory S. Paul]] (2005), ''Cross-National Correlations of Quantifiable Societal Health with Popular Religiosity and Secularism in the Prosperous Democracies - A First Look'', Journal of Religion and Society, Volume 7, ISSN 1522-5658 http://moses.creighton.edu/JRS/2005/2005-11.html </ref> From the conclusion in the article by Paul, based on a study of many western countries but, with a focus of the bad outcome of the US : "Pressing questions include the reasons, whether theistic or non-theistic, that the exceptionally wealthy U.S. is so inefficient that it is experiencing a much higher degree of societal distress than are less religious, less wealthy prosperous democracies."
